Dear Ms. Love:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for Western Wayne DHHS completed on
October 2, 2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required.
Violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am unavailable and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Deborah Will, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a – j)
One of two foster child files were noncompliant.
One foster child was replaced four times in late 2018.
Actions summaries (DHS69-b) documenting the changes
were not completed until three months after the changes
occurred.
Another child was replaced once and the new DHS69-b
form was used. That documentation was completed on
time.
(Repeat violation)
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by
section 5111 of 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All of the
following apply:
(ii) A copy of a waiver addressed to the department of
community health signed by the parent stating
immunizations are not being administered due to religious,
medical, or other reasons is sufficient documentation of
immunizations.
One of eight foster children was not up-to-date on
immunizations. The foster care worker stated the parent
4

refused vaccinations. However, there was no waiver letter
signed by the parent in the child’s file.
(Repeat violation)
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
One of eight foster children did not have a dental exam
within 90 days after placement.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall have documentation from the medical or
dental provider of all medical and dental care received by a
foster child.
For one of eight foster children, a dental exam was
reportedly completed based on an insurance statement.
However there was no evidence from the dental provider
that it was completed.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
One of seven ISPs was 25 days late.
(Repeat violation)
5

R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of thirteen USPs was 22 days late.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.49 Medical passports must be updated quarterly
Three of eight foster children were missing a quarterly
medical passport.
(Repeat violation)
ISEP 6.33c PATPs must be signed by the parent/guardian
One of twenty medical passports was not signed by the
parent/guardian.
(Repeat violation)
6

3.) The facility is in compliance will all additional DHHS policies except for the following:
FOM 802 Mental health screenings must be completed within 30
days of admission. (ie screening completed by a medical
professional; or ASQ/Pediatric Symptom checklist completed,
signed and dated by the foster care worker with scoring y
completed and attached to determine whether or not a mental
health referral is needed)
Six of eight foster children did not have a mental health
screening completed within 30 days of admission.
(Repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-08C PATPs must be provided to and signed by the caregiver (in
a timely manner)
Nine of twenty PATPs were not provided to or signed by the
caregiver or were not provided in a timely manner.
(Repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-6H Two visits a month in the first two months of a placement.
One visit must be in the home
One of eight foster children was not visited four times in
the first two months.
FOM 722-06I Monthly sibling visits for siblings who are split
One of four foster children whose sibships are split missed
three sib visits (in Nov 2018, March 2019 & August 2019)
(Repeat non-compliance)
FOM 722-06B FTMs are to be held quarterly
Three of thirteen required FTMs were not held quarterly
7

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Immunization waiver letters should be addressed to the Department of Community
Health.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was supported in continuing their previous corrective action plan to
designate time each week for social service workers to enter social work contacts
and upload documents into MISACWIS.
It is important that IEPs and school progress reports are uploaded into
MISACWIS when applicable.
It was recommended foster care workers provide the most recent PATP and
quarterly medical passport to caregivers at the first visit after the service plan
is completed.
EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
The agency had no DCWL complaints or investigations during this licensing
period. There were no safety alerts identified by the DCWL Analyst.
The following citations and acceptable corrective actions plans were submitted
for the Interim Inspection of 2018:
R 400.12205 (8) (b) Required staff (caseload ratio)
R 400.12404 (7) (a – g) Placement (placement outline & supplement)
R 400.12405 (3) (a) – (h) Change of placement (DHS69-b)
R 400.12413 (1) (d) Medical & dental care policy (overdue immunizations or no waiver)
R 400.12418 (2) (a) Development of service plans (late ISPs)
R 400.12511 (1) Independent living contract (late final USP)
ISEP 6.49 Quarterly medical passports
ISEP 6.33c PATPs signed by parent guardian
SRM 103 Social service worker minimum training hours
FOM 802 Mental health screenings
FOM 722-08 Supervisor signature on service plans
FOM 722-08C PATPs signed by caregiver
FOM 722-6H Quarterly unannounced home visits
FOM 722-09C Closing action summary for terminated youth
8

VI. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, ISEP requirements and/or DHHS policies. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be issued a
renewal of their regular license.
